They bought it in 2020 for 2B. Four years later the company as a whole is now worth 2.2B and they are talking about spinning it out. I think you had a period 23 years ago where people were getting out and making up for time they spent inside. Then you had a period where the pent up demand started to cool off and normalize and now it has continued to do so right into a period of concerns over the consumer, who seems increasingly cautious about spending on things like this. I dont know. I look at it and it feels like theres something there and its not just 100 a fad. At the same time, I dont think management seems all that great. So I think you had something that maybe overearned for a while, normalized and is now facing further concerns as people worry about discretionary spending. I dont think its a fad, its an interesting concept but perhaps a time period during covid gave people unrealistic expectations about normal demand? Management seems soso and the fact that they are already talking about giving up on it isnt exactly encouraging. I dont own it, but it feels like something Id buy a little of as a lottery ticket coming out of whenever the next recession is.

I love the fact they have a CEO founder who is pretty rad. How can you not love this In 1995, Beck became a toolanddiemaker apprentice at Fisher Paykel company. While working there, he taught himself and used the company workshop to experiment with rockets and propellants. Using these tools and materials, he created a rocket bike, rocketattached scooter, and a jet pack. Later, Beck moved into product design department and bought a cruise missile engine from the United States. It was while he was working at Fisher and Paykel he met his wife, Kerryn Morris, also a designer. He then worked in New Plymouth as a project engineer on a yacht. Also they are really smart with their capital. When Virgin when bankrupt, Rocket Lab was able to buy a lot from them. They also made some great acquisitions to make them not only a launch company, but also they build the stats and other things, like space solar panels. They also are doing more launches for NASA, so they are operating in both government and commercial spaces.

If you are that kid, just trust yourself and be patient. Japan investors threw the taper tantrum of the century. Boj knows whose boss now, wont be trying anything again.

It goes beyond the carry trade. Japan is an exportdependent economy that thrives off a weak currency. The BOJ is only now acknowledging the entire Japanese market is constructed around the assumption ZIRP is a permanent feature.

The Yen was weaker than USD and other currencies in part because the BOJ didnt hike rates with inflation like most other CBs. The put pressure on the Yen and it devalued from 100 Yen 1 USD to 161 Yen 1USD from 20202024. 2 weeks ago the BOJ raised the interest rates from 0.10 to 0.25. While 0.25 seems low, the rate of increase is a 2x while other CBs are already cutting interest rates. This is why the Yen can be a recession trade. Because the spread bw US 10 year interest rates and the Japanese 10 yr interest rates narrows as the Fed cuts US rates putting tailwinds behind the Yen for appreciation against USD. My take is the Yen was always due to appreciate against the USD once the Fed signaled interest rate cuts. The surprise BOJ interest rate hike just added a little gasoline to the Yen appreciation trade. Of course all these degenerative gamblers taking out Japanese Yen loans using USD to buy US Treasuries and Tech stocks got caught with their pants down and are forced to sell some assets to cover their increased borrowing costs. As they sell US Treasuries, tech stocks, and other assets to buy Japanese Yen to cover their increase borrowing costs, this becomes a doom loop as the Yen moves higher and the assets they sell move lower. The Yen carry trade unwind isnt close to being unwound yet. Their will be more forced margin call liquidations of assets to cover these loans as the Japanese Yen continues to appreciate vs USD. Now the question is the speed of this Yen carry trade unwind. If it is slow move higher in the Yen, than NO financial markets wont blow up. If the Yen appreciated by 10 Yen per day against the USD as it did Monday, than yeah the markets could blowup.

The 40 years of disinflation from offshoring business operations, relying on global FX arbitrage, and exploiting the gap between raw materials from Third World countries and valueadded goods developed under First World supervision is over. Services inflation has not abated and thats manifesting in the slew of layoffs that are starting to crop up across most industries. In such a case, goods deflation is a curse that forces businesses to cut down on personnel headcount and anything else that will preserve their margins.

Call me a skeptic. Whether you use GAAP, nonGAAP, or dedicated CPA analysis, e.l.f. has a minimum PE of 60 TTM and a maximum of 85. Their margins and ROA are amazing, but the market is pricing it as if those will go up 34x I doubt this company could ever break a ROA of 100, let alone 200280. Neither the TTM nor FWD PEG 0.8 for GAAP, 3.4 for nonGAAP support the thesis they will achieve that level of growth. Its a great company cursed by hype and unrealistic expectations.

If we rely on traditional metrics, PE TTM is 1124 and PE FWD is 429. Understandably outrageous, given that ASPN was operating at negative EPS and ROA for the last 5 years theres overlap between the profitable and unprofitable periods that makes TTM unreliable for the FWD stat. My concern is even at the current price, it is standing at 190 PE with around 2.5 ROA from 0.3 last year. The market is speculatively taking that ROA increase and assuming the multiple 67x YoY will be replicated over time instead of the raw delta. With the specialty chemical industry having a median of 1718 PE, youd need a 10x increase in EPS just to get ASPNs current price to the slightly rich side. This is feasible in a 10year span given revenue growth and guidance, but all that expansion is already priced in.

replies.text: You dont see it when you look at the revenue, but UpWorks growth has been declining and pretty much has come to a halt. Gross services volume is basically the same as it was a year ago. Revenue is only up because they keep increasing the take rate. 19 of what the clients pay now goes to UpWork. Their revenue guidance for Q3 is less than what they made in Q2. So they might enter a phase of negative growth now. Caused by declining usage which cannot be offset by further increasing the take rate. They keep focussing on enterprise deals and neglect the marketplace experience. Although the marketplace is the 6x bigger business. Clients who use the marketplace still get 3 ! invoices and receipts per week ! even if they just work with one freelancer. Who wouldnt want to add 19 to their freelancer cost and the hassle to add 12 documents per month to their tax paperwork? TlDr They focus on their sales team, neglect the product, make it more and more expensive, usage growth declines. They still have a great starting point as the market leader in work marketplaces. But unless they change the approach, I think nothing will come out of it. If the business slips away, my hope is that a new, more product oriented CEO will come into play.
Assymetric to the downside.
Ive been on Upwork for years It is straight ass these days

Thank you for sharing your thoughts. I do agree that there is still work to do, however, the take rate is much much lower compared to Fiverr. I do think the invoicing part can be improved, I know theres a giant project in regards to the VAT calculation.

Im not saying the increase in take rate is necessarily bad. But it is also not what can make up for a decline in users in the long term. Fiverrs market cap is 30 smaller than UpWorks. So it is not a proven way forward that can be a role model for UpWork. Also their business is different. Average spent per buyer is 4x smaller on Fiverr compared to UpWork. When you commission a onetime job like a logo, it doesnt matter if you pay 100 or 130. That wont make you take the job off the platform. But when you work with a freelancer on a constant basis, you start to think about why you pay UpWork every month too. Because the only thing you get for it is the invoicing. And when that invoicing is done super badly 12 monthly documents instead of 1, 4 monthly payments instead of 1 you will think hard if you really want to continue using that service.

In my opinion, UpWork is there not only to connect the freelancer with the client but also to provide trust. it ensures that if the work gets done, the freelancer gets paid. In case of any disputes, an UpWork representative steps in. Taking a contract outside of UpWork is against their terms and conditions unless the fee is paid. Yes, clientsfreelancers can agree to continue working outside of the platform. However, if theres a dispute at any point in time, one party will be unsatisfied. In addition, both parties are back to square one, the client needs to find a new freelancer, and the freelancer needs to find a new client.

True. They offer more than just invoicing. Still the invoicing is done badly and that hurts a lot. Im not sure the other services make up for it. And currently the numbers make it seem that the concept is not working. Gross services volume was about 4B in 2022, about 4B in 2023 and might be even lower this year. Is there reason to expect that this stagnationdecline will stop and turn into growth again?

I focus on the long run, and there I expect Increase in the number of freelancers Demand for freelancers to increase UpWork has reported an increase in enterprise clients. This isnt much reflected in the revenue, and I have a feeling this is due to the terms offered. I wouldnt be surprised if they have a free trial for a certain period, that doesnt generate any significant revenue for UpWork in the short run.

Where can we see that the number of freelancers and the demand for freelancers are increasing? On UpWork, there have been 872K active clients in Q1 and 868K in Q2. Thats a decline. I dont see that they reported an increase in enterprise clients. Where can I find that info? All I see in the investor presentation is enterprise revenue. And that also declined. From 26.6M in Q1 to 26.3M in Q2. Despite them spending 47M on sales and marketing in Q2.

The active clients is an important metric. However, comparing Q2 vs. Q1 is misleading due to holidays. Every year, there is decline in Q2 vs Q1. Instead, compare it vs. Q2 the previous year. The enterprise number was mentioned in the earnings call, and is also in the 10Q report. Lastly, the sales and marketing is decreasing over time allowing for higher margins. This is not only for the enterprise clients, but for all.

I dont see the number of enterprise clients in any of their documents. What is it? Maybe you are referring to their number for new enterprise clients? That does not tell us if the overall number is increasing or decreasing.

Yes, indeed, the new enterprise clients. This number in Q2 is higher than in Q1. However, I do not focus too much on this, given that the size of the enterprise clients isnt disclosed. This is why I find the active clients a more relevant number.

So the numbers tell a clear story, right? Usage growth has died down to zero. As seen in gross services volume and active users. And with the guidance of 6 revenue for Q3, it stands to be expected that usage will start shrinking now. Despite over a hundred million Dollars spent on sales and marketing per year. My interpretation UpWorks service is good at the beginning of the user journey. To match buyers and sellers. But then it becomes a chore. Because of the weekly invoice cycle and the separate invoicing from sellers and UpWork. That makes it an 8x worse solution than direct seller to buyer invoices. UpWork gained a massive amount of users during covid. And now those users abandon the service. Its a long way down to precovid levels. It can make the business decline for years. On the upside, UpWork might have the potential to become as big as the other market place leaders. Amazon, Uber, Booking, AirBnB, Shopify etc are all orders of magnitude larger than UpWork and I dont see a reason the leading work market place shouldnt become as big as those. But I think that would require a shift in the way UpWork is run. As the current approach to growth is not working. As can be seen in the numbers.

I am not sure if the invoicing would change, and to what extent. If you are a freelancer, it is good to be paid weekly instead of monthly. As for the user growth, it isnt actually declining. The of active clients is growing. Last year, they announced a change in their fee structure. It used to be multitier 20, then 10, then 5. So, the larger the contract, the lower the fee UpWork takes. The new structure is a flat 10 fee for all. I do think some contracts were taken outside of UpWork, which led to a reduction in the average spend per client which is reflected in the Gross service volume decline. I do think this is temporary, as with any price increase decision made.

The 0.46 in active clients they reported in 2024Q2 is not active clients in that quarter. But in the last 12 months. So I dont see a reason to think that is a seasonal effect. In 2023Q2 it was 0.6. In 2022Q2 it was 1.77. So basically what the number tells us is that they lost more clients in 2024Q2 than they won in 2023Q2. Still, the 6 active clients YoY look kinda good, so if those would be the only numbers we have QoQ and YoY, I would say I dont know what to think. Lets wait until next quarter. But we also have the guidance of 6 in revenue QoQ. The worst guidance in the history of UpWork. And they explain it with negative trends in the topoffunnel which could mean active clients or spent per client I think and expect it to continue We did see those trends get slightly worse in June and July And they talk about working on anticircumvention efforts in the call. You can find it in the transcript. Which should mean they will try to stop buyers and sellers from leaving the platform once they have found each other. Why would they have to do that if their users wanted to use the invoicing service they provide? The users dont want it. I dont think you can grow a business by saying We have a good service and a bad service. We give you a good service for a few days and then well force you to use our bad service forever.

Some of these trades should have been entered a long time ago. For example regional banks and certain REITs. I was buying these after they got battered and now I have some forever dividend stocks that are all up significantly in terms of principal. They will of course run more when rates decrease. In general small caps are way more rate sensitive since they typically carry more debt or in the case of banks, its interest premium. So I think it makes sense to increase exposure to small and mid caps, but long term growth, bigtech and associated ETFs VOO etc should be the bigger proportion. I dont trade. I invest, so I dont believe in these rotations of trades. You buy low and what I am saying is that a lot of interest rate sensitive stocks and bond proxies have been running up for about a year. But they will keep running up some more because, the actual effects of lower rates will kick in.

Smallcap advantage is actually caused by a statistical anomaly in the data where all smallcaps were value stocks. The value premium is given when a stock is defeated and doing poorly, versus growth which is stocks that are growing year over year. The fear is what provides a value premium. I definitely feel that. Contrarian approaches can pay off. I dont have any evidence to this but it often does feel like mainstream stock picks come from a conflict of interest. Its like they want us to buy the news when we should be selling it. But every once in a while the prosperity of their picks endures.
I like looking at market cyclicality too. I like looking at it through the lens of game theory.

I stayed away from them intel because of their fundamentals qualitatively and their declining leadership. I chose to go with Nvidia just before ChatGPT dropped. I know that was a lot of luck. But I postulate that their established leadership and accelerating market share and brilliant management put them in the position to benefit from luck. Its like that old saying luck is where hard work and opportunity meet.. I cant really remember who said it and Im probably paraphrasing. I have multiple instances of anecdotal evidence that this is true. Basically where I entered positions into great companies just before the opportunity met their hard work. You could have also seen this if you were studying economic data and their managements choices.
Thank you and Sure thing!

Im loving your playful analogy! lol good stuff! Id say its more akin to mechanics and nautical science. My approach to technical analysis combines the study of crowd behavior, and whether fundamentals could allow the valuation to get to the projected possible outcomes. It also emphasizes the use of Bayesian probability. Science, math and technology often look like magic to the uninitiated. But hey to each is own. I also believe fundamental analysis alone can still yield great results.

Thanks for the feedback! I agree, my approach could be rather time intensive when you first start. It took me a while to get to the point where I can get my ongoing research done in 12 hours per day. Do you have any tactic or aspect of your investingtrading style that really defined it?
Not a fan? Do you mind expanding on that constructively? Do you want to share your approach to investing? I was hoping to spark discussion by expressing my approach the best I could in a brief way.

They mix in good picks to maintain some semblance of competence. Of course never assign malice for what could just be incompetence. Regardless its the contrarian life for me. There is no best strategy, however there are best strategies for individuals. Regardless the majority should stick with buying mostly ETFs based on SP500 and not attempt stocks individually. Did not mean to be overly flippant your post was fine, and you put effort into it.

Markets behave within a general spectrum and capitalizing on it is fairly easy. Of course black swans come in and thats where everyone gets burned. For real fuck RSI, look at how the broad market moves away from the 200 and go by percentages and back test it and you can see how overbought things were before a correction. Use this as a confirmation with all your other analysis that you are surely using.
I stopped trying to be perfect. An 85 solution was more than sufficient, and trying to get to 95 was more likely to result in paralysis than in optimal results. Good luck!

Dont expect a lot of fanfare. I do what you do and get downvoted all the time. I love seeing the cyclical buy ins when smart money and insiders buy and you can see usually bang on when the diversions hit in technical analysis. The other thing that I do is analyze how far in an uptrend price action flies up in exuberance away from the 200 and make my sell orders accordingly and buys of course. All of this is on a strong foundation of fundamental analysis. Without the fundamentals, technical analysis means literally nothing. I would say all technical analyzers would agree unless, of course, they are day traders and thats entirely different and not applicable to this style of trading.

There is no best strategy, however there are best strategies for individuals. This is so true. Every person will have the personality or cognitive habits that mesh well with a particular strategy that might not work out well for another. I also agree that ETFs based on the SP 500 are a best practice for most people. I think it takes an unparalleled enthusiasm towards the process for someone to benefit from stock picking and even more for market timing. You gotta love the process.
That sounds like a good use of mean reversion. Like you said Id need to compare to all the other signals for confirmation but I like this longer term signal.

I like this, no such thing as a perfect setup. Thats why I like using Bayesian probability. I think looking for a perfect deterministic setup can indeed cause too much hesitation. As long as youre hitting probabilities that allow for profit with your rewardrisk ratio then youre likely to make money over the long run.
I like what youre putting down my friend. Id love to hear more about this 200. Are you using Bollinger bands to give you perspective on this exuberance?

You are optimistic about peoples general ability. Im less so, at least 70 of all people would never be able to conceptualize applying any guidelines to new situationsstocks, the learned traits area of the brain is in direct space competitionright next to the section for conceptualizing. Of the 30 whos brains are wired for it how many can do it better then the market? The number becomes very low of the population very quickly. This sort of talk tends to piss people off for whatever reason. I had a few very simple questionsmetal puzzles during interview process that would let me know. owned an engineering firm Based on the results I would hire people without a degree over someone with a engineering degree. Innate abilityhow a person brain works cannot be taught. Flip side everyone I hired were the worst spellers with terrible grammar, smaller learned traits portion of the brain.
Yes I am unaware of a technical analysis tool that does this calculation so I do it manually from the highs and the lows off the average.

No just percentages away from the 200. You can see it like clockwork when it swings up too high with the usual vicissitudes and exuberance. Lets face it, you can do the same with the EPS daily or whatever but I prefer using the 200MDA. You can get a real feel for how overbought a stock is and make a reasonable assumption of a natural pullback.

I like your first principles approach here. I do agree that some people have significant cognitive advantages. They can learn quicker. They think faster. They have better analogical reasoning. Better pattern recognition. I recently had seen some anecdotal evidence to the contrary though. I know AI and human brains arent equally comparable, but I found this really intriguing. Open AIs ChatGPT has parameter counts rumored to be in the trillions and llama 3.1 has around 400 billion parameters. Even with this vast difference in size Im looking at this like brain power llama is competing quite well because they found that if they just spend way more time training the model it magnifies its ability. I think these findings are probably having an effect on the development of GPT5 or whatever they plan to name it. This leads me to hypothesize that anyone can do anything if you have enough time and effort. This still brings you to a fork in the road. How much value will you get for the extra time and effort put into learning the craft? I dont think this will change many employers minds but it could give confidence and motivation to people who want to improve themselves.

The general rules is anyone above 115IQ can learn any career. However I was not talking about IQ, just areas of the brain that helps with certain tasks. Nasa did a study many decades ago trying to find out why some of the smartest aerospace minds in the world could not spell aerospace. Brain scans revealed the space competing parts of the brains next to each other. The general rule is you cannot teach someone to be good at troubleshoot new things if they dont have that innate ability, its not a direct IQ indication but rather a brain thing. You have a method and can do it because that is how your brain works, thinking of a box in your mind one side of it is red, can you rotate the box in your mind and seeknow where the red side of the box is even when its on the otherside of your perspective eyes 70 of people cannot do that and you cannot teach them to do it.

I admit a might have a bias here. As I was reading your comment I was flipping around a box with a single red side in my head, simultaneously thinking Where is he going with this?. Then youre like 70 of people cant do this. Im like oh . But this is why people should go the SP 500 route long term and paper trade till they feel confident in what they are doing. Then run their plans by multiple financial advisors and experts before making any detrimental decisions that could affect their lifestyle. Even if someone never makes it out of paper trading I think its a rewarding experience. I think Im in love with the process as much as the end goal.

When I originally got into self directed investing earlier this year, I found myself drawn to Nasdaq because of the high concentration of tech stocks and high past performance. As Ive learned more though, Ive read a lot of criticisms of QQQ ETFs and many of them revolve around investing in a stock exchange instead of an index. Obviously, Nasdaq is the top stock exchange in the world right in terms of growth and investing in it sounds like youd get great returns. But something doesnt feel right about investing in a stock exchange itself. Like, what if in a decade a new stock exchange over takes the Nasdaq and all the major companies move to that exchange? Would all the QQQ ETFs just drop and be worthless? My timeline for investing is 30 years and while I feel comfortable investing in something like the SP 500 over that length of time, I dont know if I have the same faith in Nasdaq. I do love the stocks in the QQQs though, and I dont want to miss out on that growth. Am I being overly cautious about Nasdaq here, or are my concerns valid?

The Sahm rule is likely not what you think it is. It is named after Claudia Sahm, not the acronym Stayathomemom. It states that when the unemployment rate 3month moving average rises 0.5 above the low of the previous year that a recession is likely already underway. We hit that point with this jobs report. It should be noted that many of these indicators have good but limited track records, that is not to say they are without merit but many people take them to be infallible when thats not the case.
it basically uses unemployment to try to predict a recession

The Yen has always had lower interest rates than the other major currencies. It was negative forever. So traders would take out loans in Yen with other currencies such as the USD, Euro, rtc and buy other assets that are appreciating such as gold, us treasuries, commodities, and stocks. BOJ raised the interest rate of the Yen to 0.25 this week to support the Yen. Now all of those traders borrowing Yen have their borrowing costs raised at the same time US 10 yr and Euro interest rates are bring cut. Thats the idea in a nutshell. Think of it is a short squeeze. I would like to say I saw this happen, but I bought the Yen at 161 just because I was looking at the 25 year chart vs USD. I wasnt expecting to be up 8 on that trade in a month. I thought maybe 8 in a year. Currencies arent supposed to move like this unless shit has hit the fan.

The past few years the yen has been getting artificially weakened v the usd due to japanese yield curve control running up against useuetc tightening. The yen carry became another way for hedge funds and large institutions to leverage bull bets basically the past few years. They borrowed in weakening yen at super low rates then went risk on with that yen, mostly in tech and the SP. It kept credit liquidity high while rates everywhere else were rising. It was part of why buffett went heavy into Japanese banks last year. Now that boj is reversing that and the yen is strengthening while their rates rise, all those bull bets have been unwinding. Boj see inflation rising and theyre acting to counter it while the rest of the world is in the middle of loosening so were seeing a drastic reversal and a strengthening yen. Anyone who is still stuck in a yen carry trade is losing a lot of money, it has been estimated that there was over a trillion tied up in the yen carry at one point, but likely hopefully much less than that by now.
The Yen has been extremely weak for decades, so U.S. traders commonly used it for FX arbitrage.

The optics of the cut are as important as the cut itself. A planned, controlled cut signals to the market that the Fed knows whats happening and is in control, instilling confidence. An emergency cut would signal to the market that the Fed doesnt understand whats happening and cant control the economy, which would stoke fear and uncertainty. The exact same cut at the exact same time could get opposite reactions from the market depending on the messaging around it.

The point is that most dividend investors specifically seek out dividend stocks to fit their portfolio. When in reality just picking good companies whether or not they provide a dividend is better. The rental example isnt perfect because real estate generates bills and requires positive cashflow to pay it off. A stock you buy once and forget about it. Instead of using dividends to buy more of the stock, you can just simply have the stock grow itself.

or that you dont want to work and receive income because you dont like paying income taxes. This is a nonsensical statement. Work generates new income. Regular rental income provides cash flow that gradually pays down the mortgage Which makes rent not at all similar to dividends. You dont understand how dividends work.

The difference is that the rent a tenant pays doesnt get directly taken out of the value of the house like a dividend does. I get the point youre trying to make, but no matter how you slice it, dividend income or even sustainable selling of stock doesnt provide the same type of income that rental properties do i.e. other people paying you their money, rather than essentially paying yourself with your own money from realizing gains. Neither provide passive income in the sense you get money from someone else. The only type of dividend income I would consider in that context is REITs. I do think those are an easy way to get dividend income from a truly external source, since those dividends are paid from rental income.

You are confusing a company cash flow with dividends, obviously companies that generate positive cash flow are GOOD no one is disputing that. The proper way to look is this because this is really what happens Sirglass me sets up SIRGLASS_LLC a limited liability company . I am 100 owner I deposit 100k into an LLC account and the LLC borrows 400k to buy a 500k property Things go well , I rent it out and I have some positive cash flow after taxes, insurance utilities, and loan payments after some period of time Now my LLC has 100k cash and lets say I think I only need a 50k cushion so I have some excess cash. of 50k inside my LLC. Now I could do some things here 1. I could use the excess cash to pay down my mortgage , Not now I have more equity ownership but I have less cash , I owe 50k less on the loan, but now I have 50k less cash. No magic way to create value here, my assets go down by 50k because I have 50k less cash, but my liabilities go down by 50 because now I owe 50k less. 2. I could upgrade my property , buy new efficient heat pumps or maybe better more efficient water heaters, or install solar panels , or replace the roof if it needs it, or just try to make it nicer so I can justify higher rent, in theory this should increase the property value . Again the property should increase in value, but once again I now I also have 50k less cash . Now there is a risk here, I could spend 50k on some solar panels , maybe they just dont work well, they produce little energy , they look ugly and its basically a 50k loss, or more because I have these ugly panels on my place that do nothing . Or maybe they work great, and not only do they look great I can now advertise my property as green hey it has its own solar panels , and not only does it increase my property value by 50k or more, but now because my property is green I can demand higher rent because hey I am green , and people like green stuff. So while my bank has 50k less, my equity is 70k more, and I can also raise my rent and people will pay a premium because they like the idea of a green property 3. I could take a distributiondividend and move money out of my LLC what will decrease the value of the LLC because now its not holding 50k cash, but now I personally am 50k richer. Since I own 100 of LLC my net worth does not change My LLC bank account has 50k , my personal bank account is 50, but since I own both bank accounts nothing has really changed. So whats the better option here, none of them magically create any value, 13 are a safer bet with excess funds but no value is really created . 2 maybe but there is also risk here, I could spend 50k and get nothing out of it.

Remember that throughout history, dividends were a given. The dividend yield of the SP500 was never below 3 until around this century, and often much higher. And one of the classic ways of valuing a company was to calculate how much dividend could be expected from it, in fact, that was really the whole point of owning shares of a stock. Only in recent times, mainly due to the rise of tech companies, do we not only not expect a dividend, but we shun them. Whether this trend is here to stay or is temporary remains to be seen. Is it a shift in the way businesses are run or is it recency bias? A lot of investors correctly observe that growth stocks have trounced dividend stocks, and they are correct that it is total return that matters, not income. But what is less certain is what is going to be the best way of achieving those high total returns in the future. I also think that the issue of tax drag is overblown. Yes, more taxes mean less returns, yet it is often not mentioned that tax you pay on dividends is included in your cost basis if the dividends are reinvested. In other words, by paying today, you will pay less when you sell your investment. Whether this is good or bad depends on your situation. Its exactly the same type of analysis as choosing to invest in a Roth or traditional IRA. Do you pay the tax now or later? Obviously paying now has benefit for a lot of people, otherwise Roths wouldnt be popular. For me, paying 15 on dividends now vs 12 or more later isnt a huge problem. Currently, because valuations are so high, Im putting in new money outside of IRAs into dividend funds only because I think it will outperform in the future, I will enjoy the income in retirement, and I feel it is better than a value fund because the quality of companies are better.
If you like it and it motivates you to invest, go for it. Why do you think you have to bring others aboard?

The one advantage of dividend stocks over bonds is that dividend payments usually increase over time and hopefully keep up with inflation. So the 3 that you might get from a dividend can be considered a real yield, whereas if you are getting 4 from a treasury, after inflation that will be less than 1.5. And as those of us with bonds have harshly learned recently, is bonds will get crushed during inflation. Im not saying dividends are less risky they can go down during recessions. But for stable income, if that is your goal, a mix might be a good idea for more stability and less dread of stock market gyrations.

Yea OP is confusing a companies cash flow with dividends Of course you want a rental property to generate free cash flow , to make a profit after all expenses. Just like you want a company to do the same , no one is disputing that. And the more cash a company or rental property makes, the better. Once again no one is arguing against that point.

You are leaving out an important fact, dividends were the only way to return excess cash to share holders , yes you could sort of do tender offers but usually you needed a larger type shareholder to buy out and you usually had to offer some premium to them so it wasnt really that great of an option . And it was sort of unfair , usually only large owners got these tender offers where they could get a premium, if you owned a few shares usually you could not take advantage of this Now companies can just buy shares on the open market without paying a premium, they just buy at the market price , this is beneficial because the people who want to sell can sell, people who want to hold can hold. So now there is not only 1 way dividends to return cash to share holders. Also your argument is mostly based around value stocks what may have some overlap with dividend stocks but they are different concepts. Not all value stocks need to pay a dividend

Yes, this is a good point, and it may very well turn out that the deemphasis of dividends is here to stay. However, there is still a benefit of dividends over stock buybacks. Stock buybacks is typically done on an adhoc basis, so there is no expectation of when or if that might occur. Dividends are typically declared ahead of the time, and while not a promise, is at least a statement of intent that there will be regular return of income to the investors. For companies in the growth phase, buybacks would be superior because they give the company more flexibility. But for companies in the cash cow phase, investors might prefer the promise from management that a portion of the profits will be paid out. And one other benefit of dividends that I didnt touch on psychology. Investors, particularly retail investors, dont like to sell stocks during a downturn. Dividends can help retirees sleep at night and actually spend their savings and help investors keep more in the market rather than overallocating their bond or cash portion.

The counter argument is that you do not need dividend income for cash flow You can always sell x of your portfolio to generate cash flow if you need it. Also the biggest advantage is it your choice when and how much you sell. If you dont need any cash flow you can just not sell and not take a tax it, you cannot really refuse a dividend, now this really does not matter in a tax advantage account But generally if you portfolio goes up 7 on average over the years, you can with draw 4 yearly and your position will grow and potentially keep up with inflation . The argument is sequence of returns What if the market drops 15 a year for like 10 years straight you will run out of money Well yea that is a risk, but you also have risk with dividends , what if your dividend company cuts their dividends ? And when this happens usually the company stock also craters . So yea equities are risky , even dividend stocks .

Stock buybacks is typically done on an adhoc basis, so there is no expectation of when or if that might occur. I can see this both as a draw back and benefit. If a company starts paying a dividend with a goal of increasing it, well management may make more constrained decisions, they know they are expected to return X back per year and grow X per year and return it and will act accordingly so I agree this may be a strong incentive to management to carefully manage the companies cash flow It can also be in some cases a burden , I have seen companies get in trouble but they keep paying the dividend , way too long. They basically will do everything but cut the dividend and this can be detrimental to the company. GE, several banks and they do not cut the dividend until they are in crisis and are forced to . And one other benefit of dividends that I didnt touch on psychology I have to agree on this, the preference to dividends is not logical its irrational mental accounting, but if it makes you sleep better at night , even for irrational reasons that is a benefit

replies.text: historical data has shown that dividend paying stocks tended to outperform their non dividend paying counterparts. If dividends dont inherently add value, why is this the case? Life is not just about numbers. And the differences between dividend payments and stock buybacks involve a great deal more than math. Dividends are usually distributed in a systematic way, and cutting dividend payments is seen as a very bad sign. So, a dividend is in effect a statement by management that they believe the company can perform and continue to deliver into the future. Boeing is a case study. Prior to 1998 investment in new aircraft programs and the companys reputation was seen as a way to protect investors, and the dividend, well into the future. Post 1998 the Jack Welch school that came to control the company was focused on short term results and stock buybacks. The difference between Boeing today and what is called in the industry legacy Boeing is stark.

In certain countries like Australia dividends have special treatment from a tax perspective also, which makes it an attractive component of total return.

Its a nice thought experiment, but youre taking it too far in your conclusions. Assumptions like management will always spend money in good faith to maximize earnings are useful if you want to make a world that is spreadsheetcompatible, but massively off the mark from the real world. In the real world management has incentives like getting the stock price to a certain number by a certain time to get a payout, future be damned. Creating unrealistic narratives about future earning to justify or increase PE ratios you know are excessive. Tech is a huge part of the SP500 and these problems are very common in tech. Around the dotcom crash this all got so bad that nobody could give out any dividends at all, for fear of demonstrating that they dont have endless golden geese lined up that the money would be better spent on. These days theyve gotten a little better about this and your Apple, Microsoft, and Google at least pay out a nominal dividend of like 0.51. Investors regularly get their money pissed up the wall like this in tech, when they would have been much better off just receiving it as a dividend than having tens of billions wasted on the metaverse with promises that all life would revolve around this concept in a few years, only to have them say actually never mind its all fake after a few years of stock options vesting at high valuations. Of course, were in the middle of a similar bubble with AI, so this all seems quaint now, but trust me, in a few years there will be a lot of people saying I wish they had just given me the money. So yeah, I like a small dividend, just to maintain a culture that this is my money they are playing with, and if they dont have a good use for it then Ill take it. A lot of this applies to share buybacks as well, although theyre prone to more bad incentives as they work through share price, so management is incentivized to do them even when the stock is already overvalued, and the personal incentives mentioned above etc.

Part of the reason for dividends is they discipline management through requiring payouts and ensures they dont squander the companies cash. I guess you could make an argument for stock buybacks since they are more tax efficient but because they are expected at regular intervals they dont quite have the same ability to discipline management.

However, dividends themselves are an irrelevant criterion for investment selection. thats not what Modigliani and Miller claimed. Their research has been consistently distorted and misrepresented over the years. Note that MM didnt say that dividends were irrelevant they said, under their extremely narrow conditions, that dividend payout ratios should be irrelevant to the overall value of the firm. That is a specific finance claim, not a generalized disregard for dividend payments. It is not what MM said its what people now think they said. Theres a big difference. Empirical evidence, such as the drop in stock prices on the exdividend date, supports this theory. When a dividend is paid, the share price tends to decrease by the amount of the dividend, as cash leaving the company is reflected by a reduction in book value per share. Thats not just just a market tendency, its whats required to happen. All opening bids and offers are adjusted down by the amount of the dividend and any shareholders at the open are entitled to the dividend.

The Dividend Irrelevance Theory, proposed by Modigliani and Miller MM in 1961, asserts that dividend policy has no impact on a firms value or cost of capital in a frictionless market. Under this theory, a companys value is determined solely by its earnings power and investment decisions, not by how it distributes its profits. Whether profits are retained or distributed, the firms underlying valuation remains the same. I highlighted the key phrase in that paragraph you wrote. That lines says taxes, law changes, wares, natural disasters, and diseases, and criminal activity are Irrelevant. Clearly that is not the case if you look through history. The resent a pandemic and hurricanes and Russias invasion of Ukraine have all had massive impacts on society and many businesses did not survive. Looking further back Enron was seen as a great investment until it was people discovered that the executives lied about the companies performance and illegally manipulated energy prices in california. A tariff war was initiated by US government in 1929 resulted in in an about 60 drop in trade and the SP500 loosing 13 of it value in about 2 days. Add in WW2 and the economy needed 14 years to recover. That one assumption in the theory make it it invalid. Things beyond the control of the company can quickly turn it from profitable to a money looser and eventually kill the company. Look at the dividend return and capital gains earnings of the SP500 seperately 74 of of the funds performance comes from reinvesting the dividends Only 26 came from capital gains. Clearly the dividends from the index, as small as it is, are important. Clearly the divided irrelevance theory is not a valid theory. this video also explains the problems with the theory.

Everything you say is true but investing is a personal situation driven game. During your accumulation phase you would be wrong to have any allocation other than a diversified portfolio that is spread between growth and value with some adjustment for whether we are in a Value or a Growth phase in the market. In the Early Accumulation phase you should be heavily invested in equities as you dont much care about down cycles as you have little money at risk. In the late accumulation phase you start to build in a strategy for up and down markets as you now have some principal to protect. In the Preretirement stage you start to worry more about beta and less about alpha particularly if you have done a good job of accumulation. In Retirement your goals are preservation and income, so less beta is more important than excess alpha unless you are late to the party. Assuming you have hit your goals, then joining rdividend and forgetting a growth allocation makes total sense. In that stage assuming a good number, you can use the dividends and leave the kids the equities at whatever value they may have when you are gone. People throw around a 45 wdl number which is doable with a dividend stream and no stock sales if you pick your stocks correctly.

Id actually argue that all else equal, dividends are actually a structural headwind to returns. As you point out, dividends are just a mandatory liquidation of a portion of the market cap of the company. Any investor who owns the stock via a basket e.g. an index fund investor who reinvests dividends is effectively going short the stock vs long the other stocks in the basket and actually reinvesting an even smaller portion than they would have otherwise because the dividend reduces the companys weight in the index. Extending the work of Koijen et al, this imbalanced flow should have a lasting price impact on the stock relative to the other constituents in excess of the fundamental change in the value of the companys assets

You would be knowledgable on a subject then, perhaps you can answer it. My understanding is, your actual numerical value of debt is essentially irrelevant provided you have the cashflow to make a lender comfortable. Is this ballpark accurate?

Correct. The most common way a lender will look at the quantum of debt they are willing to extend is a multiple on cash flow. So if you generate 100m in cash flow a year, a lender will most likely be willing to extend 300 400m or 3 to 4x cash flow. The primary reason being is a company will trade at some much higher multiple say 7 to 20 times depending on business so if youre only lent 3 to 4, you are safely inside a potential EV of the company. Secondarily, the lender wants to ensure you generate enough cash flow to cover the interest expense of the debt. There are other underwriting metholdogies though, multiple on recurring revenue or pure asset based lending against liquidation value of assets are two other common ones

content.text: Is there a point in short term investing as an individual?

replies.text: Nope
It has a stimulating effect and lowers the riskfree hurdle. Whether or not its enough to overpower the cooling economy is the question.

I think of my investing as being in parts. Long term parts dont really need to be concerned about it. shorter term stuff needs to factor that in. In the short term 25 basis points cut is good. 50 basis points is bad. I have money to deploy. If the cut is 50 I will sit on it. If its 25 basis points I will likely deploy a chunk of it. 50 basis points means the Fed sees something Im not quite seeing and that will worry me a lot. I would prefer to not toss a bunch more money into the market until I understand what that something is. Personally I think the economy will be fine, but things are in a major rotation and its having all kinds of impacts. The primary driver is the change in work habits for a large segment of the population. WFH is great for them. Its great for society as a whole perhaps, but its terrible for a slew of business models. Retail and restaurants near office buildings and along major commuter routes were priced in with commuters in mind. Less commuters is pinching those businesses hard. I saw Verizon is suffering and laying off a bunch of people. Im not surprised. A lot of people are now WFH. That means they use wifi more than the cell towers for a lot of their work. They probably need fewer phone calls and more zoom calls. This doesnt apply to everyone but in a business about margins every clump of people with changing habits has an impact.

If a bigger than expected cut happens? No nothing would change my long term outlook which is that rate cuts will happen. Whether they cut more or less next week doesnt matter except if they make a dip, Ill buy it.

Simpleminded me has thought for 6 months that the first 14pt cut will make the markets, well, not explode exactly, but the news will be greeted with enthusiasm. Borrowing costs go down, profits go up, stocks go up, yadda yadda. As we get closer and closer to that event, enthusiasm seems to be fading. Whereas over the summer a 12pt cut would have been seen as the Fed finally admitteding that their actions were holding back corporate profits, today that same 12pt is more likely being seen as an Oh shit does the economy really need stimulating already? and maybe its not the good news that everyone had hung their hats on in June and July. Im easily described as an eternal optimist, so remain hopeful that the first small rate cut will be seen as positive for the economy AND the markets theyre not the same, right? and increased profits are on the nearterm horizon.

The FOMCs decision on interest rates always seems to stir the pot. Personally, I think their cautious approach is a reflection of the uncertainty in the current economic climate. Balancing inflation and growth is no easy task. What are your thoughts on how this might impact longterm investment strategies?
0.25 cut before election which is what Ive been posting for a while.

Rate changes can cause losses in bond funds. Long bonds have most interest rate risk. If you are reaching for extra yield and invest in long bonds, you can get whipsawed by rate changes. Shorter bond duration is less risk. Fair warning.
a quarter or a half point makes absolutely no difference at this point. retail ? pfft. the employment numbers will drop. too many layoffs now.
Yes. The Business Cycle is the only known way to successfully time the market

At this point, the FOMC results are a signal, one of a number. And btw, wall street knows all the signals already, and still might react on emotion, but dont think you can out think wall street. Rate cut of 25 basis points already built into prices, and pretty much emotion too. Likely little affect. Look at other signals, e.g. inflation, unemployment, and invest for a longer term. If only 25 points, then the fed thinks it will be a soft landing, and everyone is expecting even with that a rebound both because of fundamentals and the 4th quarterelection history. Depending on the landing, real estate should do well beyond the soft landing. Other interest rate sensitive investments likely to do better as we land, but be ready to rotate back into growth if thats your objective. Timing is not a good strategy, but octnovdec, look to buy the dip.. Rate cut of 50 basis points Im no professional, but Im not with wall street on this 6040 likely. With inflation somewhat tamed, the Fed turns to unemploymentlabor market finally, after Powell has been blaming labor market for inflation, rather than rebalancing after, lets see, 50 years of stagnant wages despite big productivity increases and record profits and huge price increases over those 50 years. But I digress. But guess what, the labor market is in modest good shape, as are other recent stats. I am a contrarian and dont think well see 50 points cut. And if we do, emotion will take over and maybe panic that we are in for a hard landing, and a self fulfilling prophecy. Personally, I am in a defensive posture, more than usual in interest rate sensitive or low beta defensive ETFs.
Do interests rates affect stock valuations isnt a matter of opinion. If you dont understand this you need investopedia not polling random strangers.

Do you think a theory that, the market is at all time highs with the A.I hype and an interest rate cut will actually cause turbulence by rotating to smaller caps and hurting people in the short run, has much validity? Im kind of in the careful what you wish for boat but not willing to stand by any serious predictions.

The small cap rotation has been around the corner for almost two decades...just like the exUS rotation. Im personally of the mindset that the mega caps are inflated because theyre the only group pushing measurable innovation and efficiency for other companies to benefit from. I personally see no reason to deviate from a growth tilt.

replies.text: Metals can be cyclical. Aluminum replaced a lot of steel to make vehicles lighter meet tighter fuel efficiency standards. Copper and nickel are in the EV battery production stream. The US let aluminum production die back starting from the 1980s, even though it was considered a strategic commodity. I check on NUCOR and ALCOA once in a while. The postpandemic bump should not have been a surprise to anyone. Keep an eye on electricity. Thats how alumina ore becomes aluminum like smelting. These plants are direct service meaning, on the main grid with their own rectifier yards. Another thing to monitor is alumina ore extraction and processing itself. A third indicator will be emissions issues esp in China and Brazil. There are rolling mills and can forming facilities that can use recycled material, but there is a limit per production batch due to alloy requirements. I worked 15 years at an aluminum reduction facility. We used to have a wire rolling mill, too, but that part of production got sold to Chile. Norsk Hydro contracted out their production to NW US, because tolling was cheaper than making it with their resources. I still use our Norsk Hydro foam can koozies, had them out today in fact.

I think you need to understand a more fundamental thing. Two things, in fact. When it comes to crypto there is absolutely no reason for anyone, ever, to hold your money. As soon as your money is out of your wallet they can just take it. There is no technical method, and mostly no legal method, to get it back. Crypto is the scam capital of 2024. If this is what happened to you assuming whatever company you did this with was not legit and this isnt just the normal stupidity of such companies, learn the lesson and move on. Investment is about purchasing an asset that increases in value. In this sense crypto isnt an investment its appreciation in value isnt based on anything tangible but rather on hopes and dreams and, occasionally, scams. When you purchase securities as opposed to crypto, you also do so at your own risk, but you also know what that risk is, what the rules of the game are, and, more importantly, there is a clear logic and the legal framework in place. Companies and governments need cash companies need it to fund growth and governments need it to bridge over their own stupidity and to fund projects. This is financing the investor money, through stocks, bonds which are loans enables them to execute their projects and produce growths, and with growth there are returns. That is to say, financing is a necessary funding source for organizations and your benefit comes from financing them. Most people who are not involved in running a business first hand do not understand the fact that major expansion of a business without an additional funding that comes from outside the business is between improbable and impossible. This is why investing has to exist. Crypto, on the other hand, is only useful to buy or fund things the government doesnt want you to fund or buy, or running scams on unsuspecting and inexperienced people. Its not subject to any predictable rules and it is in many senses worse than casino gambling. In every casino game there are specific mathematical properties that can tell you the odds. With crypto its basically chunks of gold scattered over a minefield, at night, with people flinging poop at you as you crawl.

sp500 is filled with multinational corporations who derive much of their income in countries other than our own. They establish manufacturing and distribution networks abroad, to where many of their products never touch u.s. soil. Caterpillar is a good example off the top of my head, but there are many more.

Innovation emanates from the Liberty and freedom created by a society that meets its duties to protect minimum anthropological gateways, like running water, non prohibitive food economy, a fair justice system, broad hygiene of individual and city state, and a few others. Societys duties form arches with individual duties to selfadvancement, and to respect others freedoms. Population growth helps on the consumption side as in companies can now sell a lot more product if we have a lot more people. Population size doesnt really matter on the production side where ever increasing productivity is much more important. The stock market will keep going up if productivity keeps going up even if the population stays constant.

Japan has much higher population density than US. That results in much higher prices for real estate. Homes are more expensive, leading to much smaller homes. Thus the 1 child family. Those extra bedrooms are too expensive for the average income to afford in Japan. One child family means the overall population shrinks over time. Because two parents need to have two children to keep the population level stable. If the US wants to grow its population naturally, it needs to make home ownership affordable for working families to have kids. If the US doesnt make home ownership more affordable, and instead tries to grow through immigration, it will just lead to increased poverty with more people below the cost of living. But the US economy and stock market can still grow through innovation. While Japan has great companies such as Toyota, the culture of Japan doesnt encourage risk taking. Long story short, Japan and US are on different paths, and their stock markets are difficult to compare. Nikkei 225 has never performed like SP500, probably never will.
People here will tell you it will be fine but as we can see in Japan, it isnt fine. What they are, we will be. Plan accordingly.

Guys, if you are new to this sector, please read this message as a bit of advice from someone who has been in this investment since 2019. It is a volatile sector. Expect big drops of 20 in mid cap stocks and even more in small caps. Within a week. This happens also for the upside like we see this month for a lot of the U equities. That said, there is unbelievable valuation and immense upside to many uranium juniors and business focused on the fuel cycle enrichment etc. This sector moves at a glacial speed, and many stocks do get ahead of themselves. Do lots of homework on companies that are developers of mines. The only producers that need to be considered for a newbie is Cameco, Uranium energy Corp, boss energy and energy fuels. If you want more then look at Sprotts Uranium information on their website. Dont listen to hype on YouTube, X, and other sources. Its a great opportunity to buy a non fungible, scarce and undervalued commodity, but dont expect to make life changing money if you consider yourself an average investor, much of the easy money has been made already in the sitting and waiting. Now is the time to look for value, performance and the companies that are actually going to be able to mine this resources at significant quantities well into the future. Alongside the companies involved in the other services in the sector. This bull market is not a flash in the pan. This time for the nuclear industry, its game on.

Prior to that westinghouse which was owned by Toshiba was forecasting a similar nuclear Renaissance. They began producing 4 AP1000 nuclear reactors 2 in SC, 2 in GA the nrc retroactively changed seismic requirements for the foundations of the reactors in the middle of construction. The 2 in SC were abandoned and comprise of a 20 billion dollar hole in the ground. This also forced westinghouse into chapter 11 bankruptcy and was sold by Toshiba. There are substantial risks, which are world wide, to the industry itself. Just to keep all potential investors aware.

The uranium market is already seeing a mix of tight supply and rising demand for nuclear energy, especially as countries push for clean energy solutions. Kazakhstans recent production cuts and the U.S. banning Russianenriched uranium are only going to add more pressure to an already constrained market. On top of that, demand for uranium is expected to grow as China and other nations continue to build nuclear reactors. Prices have been fluctuating, but many experts believe they will rise again due to these supply and demand dynamics. Whats also interesting is how big tech companies are now getting involved. Microsoft recently signed a deal to revive the Three Mile Island nuclear plant to power its data centers, while Oracle is building small modular reactors SMRs to fuel its AI data centers. These reactors are expected to deliver over 1 gigawatt of electricity, showing just how critical energy demand has become in powering AI growth. This could lead to even higher demand.

To add to this, you can also add the credit spread trades that are available between the countries who export uranium and who want uranium. Still waiting for liquid fluoride thorium reactor LFTR to come online. These can convert Thorium232 into Thorium233. This decays into Protactinium233, which further decays into Uranium233. Protactinium233 can be removed from the liquid salt of a tworegion MSR by reductive extraction into liquid bismuth. Basically a breeder reactor that uses a cheaper and more abundant fuel source. This style of reactor was designed in the 1950s and I honestly believe the main reason this hasnt been developed further is more due to proliferation risks than cost or feasibility. Since the Protactinium233 can be extracted rather easily and would be of high concentration, it would reduce a lot of the work needed to make a nuclear weapon. Mainly removal of neutron emitters and other purification steps to get to 95 purity of Uranium233. Uranium233 is a fissile isotope.

TL,DR from ChatGPT Summary Uranium Market Report Price Trends Since 2020, uranium prices have surged from 21lb to 106lb in February 2024, currently stabilizing at 83lb. The report suggests that this increase is only the beginning, with further growth expected. Uranium Overview Uranium is a naturally occurring radioactive metal, primarily used for nuclear energy. The key isotopes are U238 used in military applications and U235 used to fuel nuclear reactors. U235 is particularly efficient, with one kilogram producing energy equivalent to over 3 million pounds of coal. HALEU and Enrichment Highassay lowenriched uranium HALEU is critical for advanced nuclear reactors. The U.S. is investing in domestic HALEU production to reduce reliance on imports, especially from Russia, which controls a significant portion of global enrichment capacity. The U.S. has started producing HALEU domestically, supported by government initiatives. Supply Challenges Uranium supply is tightening due to depleted inventories and underinvestment in mining. Mines are expensive and slow to develop, often taking 1015 years to become operational. The market is shifting to rely more on primary mining as secondary supplies dwindle. Primary production is forecasted to decrease by 30 by 2035, highlighting a potential supply gap. Demand Growth The U.S., China, and France account for 58 of global uranium demand. As of 2024, there are 440 operating reactors worldwide, with many more planned. The World Nuclear Association predicts a 28 increase in demand from 20232030 and a 51 rise from 20312040, driven by global clean energy goals. Global Production Kazakhstan is the leading producer, supplying 43 of global uranium. However, production cuts due to delays and shortages could put further pressure on prices. The U.S. has also increased its domestic uranium production in 2024, signaling a shift toward selfreliance. Investment Insights The report suggests that mining companies are wellpositioned to benefit from rising uranium prices. Companies like Cameco, NexGen Energy, and ETFs such as URNM and NUKZ are highlighted as investment opportunities. Big tech companies like Amazon and Google are also investing in nuclear energy, emphasizing the growing interest in this sector. Conclusion The report anticipates a bullish market for uranium due to increasing demand and limited supply. With countries seeking clean energy and reducing carbon emissions, uraniums role as a key energy source is set to grow, potentially driving prices to unprecedented levels. no because unlike with other forms of fuel, uranium costs are a tiny portion of the overall cost of building and operating a reactor. the majority of the cost is the upfront capex for building the reactor 10s of billions for big multireactor plants. then, the marginal cost of loading them with reactor is almost negligible in comparison. due to how expensive reactors are to build, countries cant afford to let then sit idle regardless of uranium prices. It was calculated that 700lbs is the cutoff at which point it becomes uneconomical to keep running the reactors. this is 8x the current price. due to these factors, uranium supply is priceinelastic

Global turnover in U is pretty large but a rather small share of it ever meaningfully sees the market. The industry is vertically integrated to an incredibly high degree. This means that mines opening up or closing that do sell on the open U market can swing the price like mad. It doesnt matter to most of the industry.

Anything denominated in USD should use US Treasury bonds as the risk free benchmark. There is no risk that the US government would default, they can always print more money. Good analysis. The little I know about development of systems following Functional Safety ISO26262 tells me that Tesla vision only AI design will never be able to proof level 5 autonomy. It is escalable true, but never safe enough to be approved on the roads.

Some minor details in need of correctionclarification. Radar and lidar are also capable of detecting and classifying pedestrians either by themselves or as part of a multimodal sensor suite. In fact they can be better than cameras in some circumstances, low light as you mentioned. Some lidars also give Dopplerrelative speed not sure if Waymos does but I know AURs does. Video processing is necessarily a much more resource intensive task than processing lidar or radar data. Now everyone I know that has radar and lidar also has cameras, so that may not be important but there are probably some optimizations that having multiple sensors allows a reduction in the amount of video that needs to be processed. Rapid iteration is not a differentiator, everyone doing self driving Waymo included can push updates whenever they want. Most also use Continuous integration pipelines. Regulatory hurdles are mostly propagandafake news auto companies self certify for safety, other than FMVSS rules which are testable requirements NHTSA can verify. FMVSS rules are very easy to comply with and say nothing about autonomy. There are some FMVSS changes required to remove steering wheel pedals and other things but those changes have been in process for years and should be done soon if it hasnt already happened, not familiar with the latest status. The easy work around is to simply not delete these until the rules change, theres also a waiver process that some companies I believe have successfully completed to delete these components. The real regulatory hurdle is liability, and needing to pay out millions in damages when a court determines your product killed someone and the manufacturer is liable. In other words the only real barrier is tech readiness. Regulatory hurdles are just an excuse that wallstreet types tend to buy.

I know the company has been through a lot over the past few years. Im not saying this stock will definitely go up, but I think the chance of a turnaround is mispriced. On average, this play could be profitable. Of course, I cant go into too much detail in a WSB post. Its not about predicting exactly what will happen anyone who claims they can predict the stock market is probably just kidding themselves. But I believe youd come out ahead if we ran this scenario a bunch of times.

I see the biggest opportunities when the entire market has a solid opinion about something. Thats where you can find prices that are irrational or mispriced. It doesnt mean going against the crowd is always a winning strategy, but if you just follow what every retail trader is doing, you wont get great returns. For those looking to play it safe, ETFs like the SP 500, QQQ, or MSCI World make a lot of sense and can provide decent returns. When I think about the next 10 years, Im not too sure what will happen. Im more focused on the next 13 years. Sure, you can jump on the NVIDIA train and the whole AI hype, but while AI is a hot topic right now, weve seen four waves of AI before, each bringing new revolutionary advancements. Im skeptical about how smart these LLMs really are, and there are many other forms of AI that have potential too. Additionally, NVIDIAs valuation is influenced by factors like demand for gaming GPUs, data center growth, and the overall semiconductor market trends. However, with a 3 trillion market cap, Im curious to see if they can maintain that level. It seems heavily tied to momentum and hype, and we all know hype can fizzle out. If youre looking to play it safe over the next year, maybe consider investing in a few broad and diversified ETFs, and perhaps look into some China and India indexes, too. Overall, I think investing in Intel could be a good addition to your portfolio, but I wouldnt recommend putting your entire portfolio into it.

As of September 2024, the West continues to impose heavy sanctions and restrictions on imports of many Russian goods, particularly in the wake of the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. However, some Western countries still import specific Russian products, though in significantly reduced volumes compared to pre2022 levels. Key imports that continue to flow from Russia to Europe and the U.S. include 1. Energy Products Although many European countries have drastically cut their dependence on Russian natural gas and oil, certain imports like liquefied natural gas LNG still persist, albeit at reduced levels. 2. Metals Russian aluminum and derivative products are still imported, though the U.S. imposes a 200 tariff on aluminum and derivative products smelted or cast in Russia, and similar measures are applied to steel and other metals. 3. NonEnergy Commodities Certain agricultural products like fertilizers continue to be imported into Europe due to their critical role in food production. Overall, the proportion of Russian goods imported by the West has significantly decreased due to sanctions, tariffs, and a broader pivot away from reliance on Russian supply chains. The most prominent exceptions are energy and select raw materials, often subject to very high tariffs or specific exclusions. So in his offer letter, it basically stated, in plain English, that at any point from day 1 of him coming onboard, that if he didnt like the job, or the board didnt like him, he could quit or they could let him go, and they would have to write him a check equivalent to 1 years salary with taxes accounted for, meaning he would get to take home an actual 160k, so the actual check would need to be for a bit more accounting for his tax bracket and all... So I remember asking, I said something like... wait wait wait.... so when you reach this level, you can just start this job knowing if it doesnt work out 1 day, 5 days, 4 months down the road, at any point, not only are you making a fat salary, but the day you leave you just got a years salary ahead of time coming at you ready to go fuck all to go find the next thing? This shit is so fucked up, even more so that it was a notforprofit company. OP is holding bags. The techniques they use to protect the system are the simpliest ... mainly blacklists and whitelists. Thats ignoring XDRs machine learning, behavioral analytics, device protection profiles, the fact that you can ingest firewall alerts into XDR, etc. Oh wow you can completely bypass AV as an admin!? You know what else you can do as an admin, uninstall the AV software. BlackHat speaker was basically farming career karma for explaining how a product works, which good for him, probably looks great on his resume. NGAVs. They all work relatively the same. They all rely on MITRE techniques tactics and procedures along with IOCs to blockalert on bad behavior. The idea that one company has secret sauce when malware has relied on many of the same fundamental software vulnerabilities for decades is rediculous and I will die on that hill. I have used both CS and XDR. Both have pros and cons.

The threat model might be limited yeah but again to me its just an example of how poor ONE of their product is, think about the rest if they build stuff this way. Cortex literally showing you what regex it uses to prevent you from executing a command? Like how they dont know you shouldnt show this info? All of configuration files in plain sight that basically reveals the internals of the product.

Their PANOS has a long history of being a source of vulnerabilities that were exploited You can say this to all companies selling appliances NetApp, HPE, Cisco, Juniper, Check Point,... The thing is they all run Linux bundled with lots of ancient packages that have CVEs showing ups all the time. Enterprises and security pentest shops perform scanning regularly plus monitor CVE database, once anything shows up theyll turn their attention to appliances they own and publish reports. Not to say their stock is overpriced or not, I no longer follow this market closely.

Customer and revenue means that they are good at selling it and their product is good. You dont get to their level without a good product. One vulnerability in a module that represents 10 of their revenue is not enough to predict a market change. Again, youre just shilling S and its super clear.

OP is not wrong in his DD though, he also didnt say he know the play for PANW, so I see no harm here. Im not an AI or endpoint Security expert but I guess even with AIbased engine, the model still need to be updated regularly to deal with new malwares behavior. Otherwise, it will cause a lot of false negative.

I am holding bags because I did my DD and came up with a thesis I believe in, not the other way around. I did not randomly buy S and then started searching to confirm any bias. I do not deny PANW and CRWD are market leaders now, but I do not believe they will keep that spot forever and Im making a bet on who I think is going to be next up there. Do not misinterpret this as SELL ALL YOUR CRWD PANW!!! BOOO THE END IS NEAR kind of thing. CRWD and PANW are profitable companies now with solid fundamentals, but their success is rooted in an era that is coming to an end in my opinion. Another thing I didnt mention is that I want to capture the massive growth a small cap stock as S can provide, a growth that CRWD and PANW cant provide because their growthexpansion phase is done.

Interesting perspective. I would add two dimensions, if I may 1. With private equity, institutional investors often get a say when it comes to business decisions. They can shift their risk management from their portfolio to the asset itself. So there is less exposure to bad management or even fraud, at least in theory. 2. Given the recent boom in retail and the emergence of the neobrokers and analysts, the competition has shifted. The market will reward actors who provide the best information to their customers make them lose less money. Now, institutional investors now compete against other ,rational actors rather than ,irrational retail in this regard. Therefore, if information asymmetry has ever been a source for profits, it is less so these days.

PE is a very illiquid market. If you do invest in PE, surely is not for the dividends or for the good business. Is for pumping the company companies and sell it. And where do you sell it let me guess... public market TLDR PE is a way to buy at low valuation and unload at higher valuation on the public.

Bad Product...1000lbs heavier than Joby Its true midnight is heavier, but Id need more information to understand why this would strictly rule out competition with Joby. The Midnight airframe is very specifically targeted at slightly shorter operational routes and urban air taxi service compared to Jobys design. Additional weight could be for stability, passenger features, or the use of cheaper OEM parts instead of custom design. They have not demonstrated full flight. the video here pretty conclusively demonstrates a full size Midnight airframe flying.
